study_plan_entry.title: Introduction to QCD and collider phenomenology

free_text.Learning outcomes: The LHC collider will study particle physics at energies much larger than those probed so far at accelerator facilities. This will likely lead to exciting discoveries of beyond-the-standard-model physics. The road to such discoveries is, however, far from being trivial. [br/]A necessary condition in almost all scenarios is a fairly good understanding of Quantum Chromo Dynamics (QCD) which, apart from being interesting in itself, is the dominant source of background to signals of new physics.[br/]The aim of this course is twofold. First, after an introduction to the basic concepts of QCD, I shall illustrate several approaches to the computation of hard reaction cross  sections. Second, these approaches will be applied to cases of interests for LHC phenomenology.[br/]
free_text.Content: - Quantum Chromo Dynamics (QCD) as the theory of strong interactions: [br/]  theoretical and experimental motivations.[br/]- Peculiarities of QCD as a Quantum Field Theory[br/]- The Lagrangian of QCD and its properties (among which, asymptotic freedom)[br/]- Colour algebra[br/]- Approaches to the computations of hard reactions in high-energy collisions[br/]- Altarelli-Parisi equations and PDFs[br/]- Fixed-order computations[br/]- Resummations[br/]- Event Generators (Monte Carlos)[br/]- Applications to phenomenology: vector boson, top pair, Higgs production[br/]
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Undergraduate courses on Quantum Field Theory
